'''Eagle Pass Army Airfield''' is a former [[World War II]] military airfield complex. It is located {{convert|10.6|mi|km}} north of [[Eagle Pass, Texas]]. It operated as a training base for the [[United States Army Air Forces]] from 1943 until 1945.
Later, during the [[Cold War]], '''Eagle Pass Air Force Station''' (ADC ID: '''TM-188''') was a [[United States Air Force]] Radar facility. It was operated by [[Air Defense Command]] on the site of the World War II air base. Opened in 1957, it was closed in 1963.
The facility was finally closed in 1991 when the [[United States Air Force]] ended its use of the airfield, having designated the field as '''Laughlin Air Force Auxiliary Landing Field #1''' in 1962, using it as part of the pilot training school at [[Laughlin AFB]].
==History== [[File:FileːEagle Pass Army Air Field 1943 Classbook.pdf|thumb|200px|1943 Class book for advanced pilot classes at the Eagle Pass Army Air Field]] ===World War II=== The airport was activated on 30 June 1942 as '''Eagle Pass Army Air Field''' as part of the [[Army Air Forces Training Command]]. It was assigned to the Central Flying Training Command (CFTC), being under the jurisdiction of the 57th Basic Flying Training Group, 33d Flying Training Wing (Advanced, Single-Engine).<ref name="AFHRA">[http://airforcehistoryindex.org/search.php?q=%22EAGLE+PASS+ARMY+AIR+FIELD%22&c=u&h=100&F=1%2F1%2F1940&L=1%2F1%2F1947 Eagle Pass Army Air Field AFHRA Document Search]</ref><ref name="ATC">Manning, Thomas A. (2005), History of Air Education and Training Command, 1942–2002. Office of History and Research, Headquarters, AETC, Randolph AFB, Texas ASIN: B000NYX3PC</ref>
The airfield consisted of three 5,500-foot concrete runways. During the summer of 1942, three runways were laid down along with a large parking ramp and taxiway system. Four large hangars along with support buildings, barracks a street network, electric, sewer and water lines were constructed.<ref name="AFLDS">[http://www.airfieldsdatabase.com/WW2/WW2%20R27c%20TX-WY.htm Texas World War II airfield database]</ref>
In addition, Eagle Pass controlled three auxiliary fields.<ref name="AFLDS"/> * Cueves Field Aux #1 {{Coord|29|01|42|N|100|32|05|W|name=Cueves Field Aux #1}} * Pinto Field Aux #2 {{Coord|29|11|58|N|100|19|50|W|name=Pinto Field Aux #2}} * Eagle Pass Aux #3 {{Coord|28|41|23|N|100|20|56|W|name=Eagle Pass Aux #3}}
The mission of Eagle Pass AAF was advanced flying training in single-engine trainers. Its principal trainer aircraft was the [[North American T-6 Texan]]. It was a 3d-phase training base, its flying cadets having successfully completed primary and basic flight training. Upon graduation, the flying cadets were commissioned as Second Lieutenants and assigned to one of the numbered air forces for assignment to an operational unit.<ref name="AFHRA"/><ref name="ATC"/>
The 57th Basic Flying Training Group consisted of the following subordinate units:<ref name="AFHRA"/> * 367th Base Headquarters and Air Base Squadron * 1046th Guard Squadron * 354th Aviation Squadron (Separate) * 826th Flying Training Squadron (Single Engine) * 827th Flying Training Squadron (Single Engine)
On 1 March 1944, aircraft training units in the United States were re-organized and the 57th was inactivated, being taken over by the 2516th Army Air Force Base Unit.<ref name="AFHRA"/>
On 23 November 1944, the training at the base was changed to a phase one basic flying school, providing flight training to cadets with little or no previous flying training.<ref name="AFHRA"/><ref name="ATC"/>

On 19 April 1945, Army Air Forces Training Command notified the base commander at Eagle Pass that the station would be inactivated. Personnel began to be transferred to other bases and the number of personnel was decreased rapidly. All flight training at the field was discontinued on 30 April 1945 and the base was turned over to Air Technical Service Command; the base was inactivated on 1 May 1945.<ref name="AFHRA"/><ref name="ATC"/>
After inactivation, all useful military equipment was transferred from the base; the wood and tarpaper buildings were dismantled or sold. Title however, was retained by the United States Air Force and the facility was carried as a reserve airfield in the postwar years and through the 1950s.<ref name="AFHRA"/>
===Air Defense Command=== {{Infobox military structure |name=Eagle Pass Air Force Station |partof=[[Air Defense Command]] (ADC) |location= |coordinates={{Coord|28|51|36|N|100|31|37|W|display=inline|name=Eagle Pass AFS TM-188}} |image= |caption= |type=Air Force Station |code= |built=1957 |builder= |materials= |height= |used=1957-1963 |demolished= |condition= Closed |ownership= {{air force|USA}} |controlledby= [[File:Air Defense Command.png|35px]]  [[Air Defense Command]] |garrison= [[733d Aircraft Control and Warning Squadron]] |commanders= |occupants= |battles= |events= }} In 1953, the United States Air Force Air Defense Command requested a third phase of twenty-five mobile radar sites be constructed to supplement the permanent national network of sites established during the [[Cold War]]. In 1957, the Air Force returned and reactivated a portion of the reserve World War II facility; opening '''Eagle Pass Air Force Station''' on a small area of the former ground station.<ref name="Cornett ">A Handbook of Aerospace Defense Organization 1946 - 1980, by Lloyd H. Cornett and Mildred W. Johnson, Office of History, Aerospace Defense Center, Peterson Air Force Base, Colorado</ref>
The [[733d Aircraft Control and Warning Squadron]] was assigned to Eagle Pass AFS by the [[33d Air Division]] on 3 July 1957. The squadron began operating an [[AN/FPS-20]]A search radar and an [[AN/FPS-6]] height-finder, and initially the station functioned as a Ground-Control Intercept (GCI) and warning station. As a GCI station, the squadron's role was to guide interceptor aircraft toward unidentified intruders picked up on the unit's radar scopes.<ref name="Radomes">[http://www.radomes.org/cgi-bin/museum/acwinfo2x.cgi?site=%22Eagle+Pass+AFS,+TX%22&key=EaglePassAFSTX&pic=EaglePassAFSTX&doc=EaglePassAFSTX Information for Eagle Pass AFS, TX]</ref>
In addition to the main facility, Eagle Pass operated several [[AN/FPS-14]] Gap Filler sites:<ref name="Radomes"/> * Carrizo Springs, TX (TM-188A): {{Coord|28|30|10|N|099|50|01|W|display=inline|name=TM-188A}} * Laredo, TX (TM-188B/C/TM-189B): {{Coord|27|43|34|N|099|26|07|W|display=inline|name=TM-188B/C/TM-189B}}
In March 1963 the Air Force ordered the Radar site to close and operations ceased on 1 August 1963.<ref name="Radomes"/> With the closure of the ADC radar site, the majority of the station was disposed of, although the airfield was retained by the Air Force.
===Air Training Command=== A portion of the wartime Eagle Pass airfield was reopened under the name of '''Laughlin AF Aux #1''' in 1962 for touch and go landings by [[T-37 Tweet]] training aircraft based at [[Laughlin AFB]]. The wartime NW/SE (14/32) runway was refurbished and asphalted, with the runway extended to the southeast to accommodate overruns on each end. The airfield was uncontrolled and no personnel were assigned to the field.<ref name="ATC"/>
In 1991 a replacement auxiliary airfield was built in nearby Spofford {{Coord|29|07|07|N|100|28|21|W|name=Laughlin AFB Auxiliary #1 Airport}}, and Eagle Pass Auxiliary field was closed.<ref name="ATC"/>
===Current use=== With the closure of the radar station in 1963, the World War II station area was disposed of by the Air Force and transferred to Maverick County.<ref name="Shaw"/> The former ADC military family housing area was redeveloped into a government civil housing development. The local government also took over the ADC water filtration plant and a sewage disposal plant. Several light commercial and industrial sites were built on the former air base.
At some point between 1991–94, after the closure of the flying field by the Air Force, the touch-and-go runway was apparently operated as a private airfield, named Bowles Airfield.<ref>Thole, Lou (1999), Forgotten Fields of America : World War II Bases and Training, Then and Now - Vol. 2. Publisher: Pictorial Histories Pub, ISBN 1-57510-051-7</ref> <ref>[http://www.airfields-freeman.com/TX/Airfields_TX_Laredo.htm] [[Abandoned & Little-Known Airfields]]: Texas - Laredo area</ref>
In the late 1990s, Eagle Pass Municipal Airport was closed and general aviation operations moved to Bowles Airfield, being renamed [[Maverick County Memorial International Airport]] (FAA: 5T9). Today, the airport has about 50 general aviation flight operations per month, but no commercial airline service. The airport utilizes the former Air Force NW/SE (14/32) runway, its asphalt in fair condition. The airport also has a terminal and FBO building constructed on the former World War II parking ramp.<ref>[http://www.airfields-freeman.com/TX/Airfields_TX_Laredo.htm#eaglepassmuni Abandoned Airfields: Eagle Pass Municipal Airport]</ref>
The large World War II airfield not used by the Air Force or the airport remains abandoned and left to the elements. Concrete foundations of two of the wartime hangars remain, the structures torn down in the 1960s, and the large parking ramp remains, largely in a deteriorated state. One of the World War II hangars remains, it being utilized by a private firm.
The Air Defense Command radar station is largely intact. Following the radar-site closure the FPS-20A and FPS-6 towers were torn down in late 1965. Several abandoned barracks remain standing, although one of the buildings has a collapsed second floor along with the station support buildings, the operations buildings remain standing; all concrete and steel structures, largely overgrown with vegetation and deteriorated after 50 years of abandonment.
Many of the former streets of the station remain in undeveloped areas.<ref name="Shaw">Shaw, Frederick J. (2004), Locating Air Force Base Sites History’s Legacy, Air Force History and Museums Program, United States Air Force, Washington DC, 2004.</ref>
